bibl.title: Letter from Raymond O. Dart to Philip Showalter Hench, March 9, 1948

div1.p: Dart understands that Hench is interested in loaning items from his Walter Reed materials for use in the Walter Reed Exhibit that will form a part of the Fourth International Congress of Tropical Diseases Exhibition. He is particularly interested in items relating directly to the yellow fever experiments.

div1.head: Letter from Raymond O. Dart to Philip Showalter Hench, March 9, 1948
div1.opener:
Address All Communications To The Director
A1P 001.2
ARMY INSTITUTE OF PATHOLOGY
7TH. STREET AND INDEPENDENCE AVENUE S.W
WASHINGTON 25 DC.
ARMY MEDICAL MUSEUM
ARMY MEDICAL ILLUSTRATION SERVICE
9 March 1948
MEDEM
DEPARTMENT OF PATHOLOGY
AMERICAN REGISTRY OF PATHOLOGY
Philip S. Hench, M. D.
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota
Dear Doctor Hench:
div1.p:
Doctor Edward Gunn, Chief of the Army Medical Illustration
Service of the Army Institute of Pathology referred to your corres-
pondence with Doctor Wilbur Sawyer, Executive Secretary of the Fourth
International Congress of Tropical Diseases, in which mention was
made of your extensive and interesting collection of memorabilia of
Major Walter Reed, and your interest in loaning appropriate portions
of these valuable records for use in the Walter Reed Exhibit that is
to form a part of the Fourth International Congress of Tropical
Diseases Exhibition.

The Walter Reed exhibit for the above meetings is being
prepared at the Army Institute of Pathology, and a search is being
made for research and clinical records, photographs, books, etc.,
to provide background material for an accurate portrayal of Major
Reed's contributions to the solution of the problem of Yellow Fever.

There are some items on Major Reed's life available at the
Army Institute of Pathology, but few of them deal directly with the
Yellow Fever experiments. It is understood that your records cover
this aspect of Major Reed's life very thoroughly.

The loan of your original records would be of tremendous
assistance in the effort to properly portray Major Reed's contribu-
tions to medicine. The value of the records and the care that must
be exercised in handling them is fully realized. If you will consent
to the use of the portions you feel most appropriate for these
exhibits you can feel sure that they will be given every protection,
and any specific measures that you may request for their care will
be followed in detail. If necessary it can be arranged to transport
the material by air. After the exhibit its prompt return will be
effected unless you desire to contribute it to the permanent collec-
tion of the Army Medical Museum where appropriate portions would be
displayed in the tropical disease section.

Your assistance toward the success of this exhibit, and
any suggestions that you care to make for the most advantageous
display of the material will be greatly appreciated.
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, RAYMOND O. DART
Colonel, Medical Corps
Director D
